body.p: To His Excillency Thomas E Bramlette Governor of the Commonwealth of Kentucky

Your Petitioner Joseph D Faris would respectfully Represent unto your Excillency that at the March Term of the Whitley Circuit Court 1859 there was an Indictment returned into siad court by the grand jury thereof against one Speed S. Faris for stabbing in sudden heat of passion The case was continued from time to time until the August Term of said Court 1861 for the testimony of Larkin Bowlin the person Stabbed whose testimony would have acquitted said Speed S Faris of the offense charged in the Indictment as your petitioner verily believes from the Statements of said Bowlin the other Witnesses not being able to see all that took place at the time as said Bowlin did & he refused to appear as a witness in order that said Faris might be so fined convicted that at the August Term of the Whitley Circuit Court 1861 Said Speed S Faris went into trial wihtout said testimony rather than continue the case by longer and Judment went against him for fifty dollars and costs that on the 26th day of August 1861 your Petitioner Replevined the same that afterward the said Speed S Faris volunteered into the service of the services of the United States as a Soldier and on the 7th day of July 1863 did without having satisfied said Judgment & Replevin Bond & leaving no available means out of which to pay the same The your Petitioner would further represent that he has a large family to support and that he is in very
bad health so much so that he can scarcely attend to any business that there is an Execution in the hands of the Sheriff issued upon said Replevin Bond & Judgement and that if said Judgment or fine is not remitted he will be put to great inconveince & trouble to get the money to pay same off or his propety will have to sell He says that in truth and justice said fine ought to be remitted for all the proof could have gone before the jury they would not have fined him guilty & the Judgment of fifty dollars would not have been against him The aforesaid The premises considered the prayer of your petitioner is that you you remit said fine for which he will ever fill greatful

The undersigned citizens of Whitley say they believe the Statements in the foregoing petitioner are true & Join in the prayer of the petitioner They think the fine ought as a matter of justice to be remitted

J H Scott
John Tye
J C Watkins Clerk Whitley Cir Ct
Silas M Gatlift
Pleasant Polley C W C
George Lawson
E F Adkins (Jailor)
C. S. Creekmore
Tyrel Foley
Wm C Cox
R Boyel Clerk at the time
S P Brawner
James M. Adkins
James Jones
Wm. B. Ceekmore
John Smith
J. D. Gillios
Jacob Stinson
James M Barnett
J. S. Sears
H. L. Tye
T. R. Harman
I have no doubt but the foregoing statements are true and I hope that the fine will be remited
We hope your Excellency will remit this fine
Gov. Bramlett I believe the statements in the foregoing petition are true and believe the fine ought to be remitted and think you will do right to remit same

H F Finley
Comwlths atty. 12th Dist.
J L McCarty
Sheriff of Whitley County
G. W. Little Deputy U. S. Marshall for the Dist Ky --
I hope your excellency may remit the fine against Speed Farish I think enimently proper and just that it should be done

Whitley Cir Ct
Remit all except costs and part 800 S to atty
Sept 9th 1863
T E Bramlette
J D Faris
